posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: My team is considering creating a small device that could be connected to a SPARK MAX over CAN and used to drive the motor without needing to program a Rio or connect up a computer running Rev hardware client.  This would be useful for prototyping.  We are thinking the device would basically have a knob and a switch, and would be much simpler and more portable than Rev hardware client.  However, in order to do this, we need to communicate with the SPARK MAX over CAN .  We could use a micro-controller to produce CAN signals, but we would need to know what signals to send.  Is there any documentation available that specifies what signals we would need to send?  If not, does anyone have suggestions for reverse engineering the signals?  I’m interested to see if anyone else has tried this, and what problems they have encountered.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked:
Thrifty Throttle 3

Do it over PWM instead of CAN . There are a lot of COTS solutions for this type of controller.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Thanks for the help. How would we determine what signals to output?  Also, do you know of a similar solution that would work for CAN ?  We would like to use this on Talons too (with different signals but the same hardware) if that is possible

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: You can control Falcons and Krakens via PWM as well. I’m not aware of a CAN solution. I’m a wrench-turner, so my utility is nearing its end.

posts.name: N Miller (Mechanic/Electrician)
posts.cooked:
How are you connecting PWM to SPARKMAX? Which port is used?

My team usually tests Neos through USB to computer with SPARKMAXes, and then we have a janky set-up of PDH and RoboRio to test the Talon (only problem is the programmers have to program the sparkmax instead of just telling it direct values.
We bought a Thrifty Nova and Runner Board bc of this! We wanted to test brushless motors easily

posts.name: Jeremy Reed
posts.cooked:
25MustangMech1418:

How are you connecting PWM to SPARKMAX? Which port is used?

SparkMax’s come with a PWM cable that plugs into the same area as the CAN .

posts.name: N Miller (Mechanic/Electrician)
posts.cooked: Thank you! This has been really helpful-- I’m stilling getting a hang of some of the smaller nuances of electronics.

posts.name: AfterTen
posts.cooked: Did they ship the Novas and Runners? Their web page shows still on pre-order. Or is the current pre-order for a 2nd run?

posts.name: Sam Dare
posts.cooked: We have more Novas rolling in each week, but we should be able to catch up this week. Pending a large influx of new orders caveat applies here.

posts.name: Clay
posts.cooked:
This past off-season I designed and built a motor control console for my team to use during prototyping.  It’s got 4 channels, each controlled by a “flying fader” i.e. a capacitive touch-sensitive linear potentiometer controlled by a tiny brushed motor - picture a sound board at a concert venue.  The core of the system is an Arduino Mega (to be replaced later by something with a higher base clock - a Teensy 4.1 maybe), and there’s a few buttons and an encoder for saving and recalling “scenes”, and selecting the ramp rate between scenes.  Additionally there’s a “dead-man’s switch”, that serves as safety feature:  In order for any of the PWM outputs to be live, it must be constantly pressed - the idea being that in an emergency, a panicked operator is more likely to let go of it than they are to turn the thing off or slow down the motors manually or pull the plug.

I don’t have any up to date photos of it, as it’s currently at our build space being used for prototyping, but here’s a photo of it from a few weeks back in a previous iteration.

image 1772×946 79 KB

image 1772×946 79 KB

image 1772×946 79 KB

Indicator neo-pixel LEDS for each channel pulse/blink according to normal FRC motor blink codes (red-reverse, green-forward, etc). Faders will move on their own to set points when a scene is recalled, and will return to zero (neutral) when commanded to do so or when the enable button is released.  Touching the fader disables the primitive proportional control driving each fader motor.  The whole system runs on 12V (stepped down internally), outputs are Phoenix connectors so customizing it to match any wiring is easy.  I might incorporate a rechargeable LiPo pack in the future for portability, and it might get additional features for use as a diagnostic tool in our pit at competitions.

Disclaimer: About 50% of the above functionality is implemented.  All of the hardware is there, and the core function (independently controlling 4 PWM outputs with 4 faders) is working, but I’ve yet to code in many of the rest of the features.

Happy to answer any questions about getting arduino-compatible stuff to work with FRC PWM , or about this design in general. I’m considering marketing a more refined version of it in the future.

EDIT: I have personally tested the PWM control method with: REV Spark Max controllers (driving a Neo550), Falcon 500s, and Kraken X60s, and they’ve all happily responded correctly to control inputs.  You just have to send it properly configured PWM .
